Hi,

Last summer I read Jeff Hawkins' book On Intelligence. One of the take=

away points for me was that the connectivity in real brains has a lot
of r=
egular structure and order, but also some rather more messy
connectivity. I=
'm going from memory here but the pictue he paints is
one of cortical colum=
ns packed together vertically, columns have
layers (6 or so if memory serve=
s) and intra-column connectivity
appears to be fairly well understood at a =
*very* broad level, that is,
layer 1 neurons tend to connect to layers 2 & =
3, etc.

At the top of the columns we then see connections reaching out ove=
r
the tops of multiple columns, connecting up different regions
sometimes o=
ver very long distances - perhaps up to several
centimeters. It's interesti=
ng to contemplate what processes are
causing connections to form over such =
long ranges. One explanation I
quite like is that the early brain (e.g. a n=
ewborn baby) has a mass of
connections that have *not* yet been guided by a=
ny learning process -
so what is all this mass of connections doing? what a=
rrangement of
connectivity does it have and why? I suspect that our DNA des=
cribes
connectivity patterns in the newborn that are primed for learning an=
d
that as learning progresses some of these pre-existing connections are
st=
rengthened (and grow new connections locally), and some wither away.
I'm sp=
eculating that this early connectivity pattern includes some
proportion of =
long connections acting between distant regions. I
further speculate that t=
his might be partly responsible for the
various axon bundles that occur in =
the brain that broadly follow the
same path in all (most?) people (e.g. fro=
m the retina to the visual
cortex) - do 'primer' fibers grow by following a=
 DNA blueprint during
the early stages of brain development?

Also last yea=
r I came across this article that discusses work
regarding expression of bi=
ts of DNA considered to be junk acquired
from ancient viruses and the like:=


   "A special report on the human genome: The soul of an old machine"
   =
http://www.economist.com/node/16349410


I've appened some of the salient p=
arts to the end of this post. This
junk DNA appears to be expressed more in=
 brain tissue than elsewhere
in the body, and so there's a question of why =
this is and if it has
any purpose. One suggested purpose is that this DNA i=
s used as a
source of complexity in brain connectivity growth processes in =
the
embryo. It's possible that the learning processes/rules in the brain
do=
n't require any specific structure but do requrie some existing
structure w=
ith sufficient interconnectivity and 'messiness' to build
upon, and that th=
ese large sequences of 'junk' DNA (I appreciate junk
DNA is a loaded term) =
were a convenient source of messiness or
arbitrary complexity that evolutio=
n came to utilise over time.

Do you think this is possible? Likely? or jus=
t another madcap theory? :)

Colin.

"...Dr Gage studies LINE-1 elements, bits of DNA known colloquially as
jump=
ing genes. These make up about 20% of the human genome, and most
biologists=
 do regard them as junk=97or rather as parasites. Their origin
is unknown, =
though they may be the distant descendants of some type of
retrovirus (the =
same class as the AIDS-causing virus, HIV) because
they are able to copy th=
emselves using a retroviral gene called
reverse transcriptase. Generally, t=
his is a bad thing for their hosts.
If nothing else, it wastes resources. A=
nd if an element happens to
copy itself into the wrong place it can cause a=
n existing gene to
malfunction.
[...]
Five years ago he showed that LINE-1 =
elements are much more active in
the brains of mice than in their other tis=
sues. And in 2009 he and a
colleague, Nicole Coufal, showed the same is tru=
e in people. Using
sensitive sequencing methods they discovered that human =
brain cells
have around 100 more LINE-1 elements in them than tissues such =
as the
heart or the liver. That means the elements are multiplying during t=
he
process of brain formation.
[...]
Why that is remains an unanswered ques=
tion. But one possible
explanation is this. Each new brain develops by a pr=
ocess akin to
natural selection. Nerve cells grow and develop lots of conne=
ctions
with each other, and then most of those connections and many of the
=
cells themselves die. Only the fittest cells and connections survive,
leavi=
ng a working network.

In this context a way of generating variations on wh=
ich selection can
operate may actually result in better networks and thus b=
rains. The
random changes brought about by LINE-1 elements jumping around t=
he
genomes of nerve cells can yield such variation. It is a daring
hypothes=
is. But there is at least one other part of the body=97the
immune system=97=
that relies on the internal mutability of the DNA to
generate the variety n=
eeded for it to recognise all the pathogens that
nature can throw at a body=
. Though the immune system has come up with
a different solution in detail =
(particular cassettes of DNA have
evolved to shuffle round at this one plac=
e in the genome), the general
principle is the same."
